title: Why isn't 'Here Comes the Judge' by Pigmeat Markham considered to be the 1st rap song? - Quora

response.answer_text: Pigment Markham's “Here comes the Judge” is considered to be a proto rap song. The following proto rap artists have even more claim to the title of releasing the 1st rap song being more consistent in their delivery of similar material over their recorded output but are still considered Proto Rap. THE WATTS PROPHETS  Black in a White World THE LAST POETS  Debut album “The Last Poets” was released in 1970 with others following in the 1970s. GIL SCOTT-HERON  Gil Scott Heron - The Revolution will not be Televised But Poet Langston Hughes had produced albums with Charles Mingus Jazz instrumental backing on the fantasy label in the 1950s and these great artists are in that tradition, poetry with instrumental backing - Proto Rap. Hip-Hop (or Rap) as we know it today came from the South Bronx in the 1970s (influenced by Jamaican toasting over records) with innovative Jamaican born DJ Kool Herc repeatedly playing the “break” section of records to excite dancers at Block Parties and is part of the Break Dancing, Graffiti Writing & Rap trilogy that made up early Bronx Rap Music. Pigmeat Markham is not in that tradition and is Proto Rap not Hip Hop. Read “Can't Stop Won't Stop: A History of the Hip Hop Generation” by Jeff Chang for more background on the advent of early Hip Hop.
Actually it usually is for the most part. But it technically was a funk song, not a hip hop song. It just employed talking blues esque techniques that helped inspired the creation of “rapping.”
